The association of focal adhesion
that is tyrosine phosphorylated in response to platelet-de!

 

   

Focal adhesion kinase (FAK) is a cytoplasmic tyrosine kinase implicated in the signal transduction
pathways initited by integrins. However, we have previously found that platelet-derived growth factor
(PDGF) could stimulate the association of FAK with phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase in NIH. 3T3 cell
Chen, HC. & Guan, JL. (1994) J. Biol Chem. 269, 31229-31233], suggesting that PAK. migh
Participate in some of the cellular effects of the growth factors in modulating cell morphology and

jgration. In this report, we describe the association of PAK with 2 200-kDa protein (pp200) that is
tyrosine phosphorylated in response to PDGF stimulation in NIH 373 cells. Although the identity of
'Pp200 is unknown at present, We have excluded the possibilities that it i the PDGF receptor fl, tensin,
lalin, myosin or the guanosine-trophosphatase-activating:protein-associated p190 protein. Furthermore,
wwe foundgast the tyrosine phosphorylation of FAK-associated pp200 upon PDGE stimulation is largely
independent of cell adhesion or the integrity of the cytoskeleton. Therefore, pp200 and its interactions
with FAK may also be involved in growth-factorinduced celifMar effects such as the modulation of cell
adhesion of cell migration vie cytoskeletal reorganization or disruion of focal adhesions.

 

 

   

 

   

    

Chen, H.-C. and Guan, J.-L.

European Journal of Biochemistry 235:495-500, 1996.
Other support: National Institutes of Health,

From the Department of Pathology, Cancer Biology Laboratories, College of
Veterinary Medicine, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY.

PUBLICATIONS 0054244

summary: Focal adhesion kinase (FAK) is a cytoplasmic tyrosine kin enzyme implicated in the signal transduction process. FAK is linked with a 200-kDa protein (pp200) that is phosphorylated in response to platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF)
